awd_abstract_narration:
There is a long period during the Arctic fall, when much of the soil profile is suspended near 0°C. The investigators propose that this time of year may hold key information needed to better understand how Arctic ecosystems can be affected by climate change. The investigators hypothesize that there exist specialized cold-adapted microbes, which produce methane, a potent greenhouse gas, and that these microbes are active during this period when much of the soil column is at the freezing point. The investigators also argue that these specialized microbes may be responsible for a large fraction of the annual methane released from Arctic soils to the atmosphere. The study will test whether such specialized cold-adapted methane producing microbes are active during this period, and if so, how much they contribute to the annual soil flux of methane. To test this hypothesis, this study will bring to bear, field, laboratory, and computer model simulations.

This project aims to predict how the Arctic will respond to current and future climate change, and to better inform decision makers. This project will also continue a well-developed outreach program involving local communities and students from the North Slope of Alaska and San Diego.

Flux tower measurements have shown steady and significant methane emissions well into the Arctic fall, when the soil profile is nearly isothermal at zero degrees celsius. The investigators argue that this fall flux is maintained by specialized cold-adapted methanogenic microbial communities that live in the soil column. The study will test whether such specialized cold-adapted methanogenic communities are active during this period, and if so, how much they contribute to the annual soil efflux of methane. The proposed study includes field isotope work, laboratory incubations, methane flux monitoring, and modeling. The modeling aspect of the work was added as a response to suggestions from a previous panel.

Intellectual Merit: This grant identified the processes controlling CO2 and CH4 emissions during the fall period, discovered the occurrence of a later fall soil freezing during the last two decades which correlated with higher atmospheric CH4 concentration from terrestrial ecosystems in the Arctic (Arndt et al., 2019a), identified how soil freezing was associated with a sudden increase followed by a drop in soil CO2 concentration suggesting a peak emission to the atmosphere not captured by the ecosystem scale eddy covariance towers  (Wilkman et al., 2021), defined the role of the spatial heterogeneity on CO2 and CH4emission during the growing season and the fall period (Reuss-Smith et al., 2019; Hashemi et al., 2021), identified how snowmelt and growing season length affected the carbon dynamics of tundra ecosystems (Arndt et al., 2019b, Arndt et al., 2020), allowed identifying a microbial community active during the cold period (Lipson et al., in preparation), majorly advanced the development and application of a microbial-explicitly model - CLM-Microbe, by improving the model representation of methanogens and methanotrophs in the Arctic (Wang et al, 2019, 2021) and has resulted in >25 peer-reviewed manuscripts; supported the research of five PhD students, two master students, six undergraduate students, with considerable interaction with lead scientists in the field, and included the project results in large undergraduate courses at SDSU. Below a more detailed summary of the main scientific results from this grant. Our team:

  • Discovered that the zero curtain is extending later into winter (2.6 ± 0.5 days/year from 2001 to 2017) and that this later soil freezing is associated with terrestrial fall CH4 enhancements, highlighting the importance of the persistence of unfrozen soil layers in the fall for increased terrestrial CH4 emissions in the Arctic (Arndt et al., 2019a).
  • Identified the processes occurring during the zero curtain, showing how soil freezing can result in a sudden change in soil CO2 concentrations which suggests the occurrence of a peak CO2 release which was not captured by eddy covariance measurements (Wilkman et al., 2021).
  • Defined the role of spatial heterogeneity on the CO2 and CH4 emission during growing season (Hashemi et al., 2021; Reuss-Smith et al., 2019) and during the zero curtain (Hashemi et al., 2021), highlighting how higher growing season gross primary productivity were associated with larger fall zero-curtain CO2 emissions, reducing both variability in annual budgets and carbon sink strength of more productive sites (Hashemi et al., 2021). Surprisingly, while the spatial heterogeneity was important in explaining a substantial percentage of the variability in CH4 emissions during the growing season (Reuss-Smith et al., 2019), the fall zero-curtain CH4 emissions were equal across different landscape types (Hashemi et al., 2021), indicating site variation has little effect on CH4 emissions during the fall despite large differences during the growing season.
  •  Identified the role of snowmelt on the vegetation development of these arctic systems depending on their moisture level (Arndt et al., 2019b), and the impact of freeze–thaw processes on CO2 and CH4 fluxes, particularly through redox effects in spring (Arndt et al., 2020).
  • Through incubations and analysis of soil RNA, we found that the metabolically active zero-curtain microbial community was dominated by a single Methanothrix species, and had a lower Q10 for methane production than the summer community. We discovered cold-adapted genomic signatures in metagenome-assembled genomes of the dominant Methanothrix and a novel methanogenic species in the order Methanomicrobia (Lipson et al., in preparation).
  • Improved the CLM-Microbe model in simulating CH4 cycling, parameterized the model with site-level CH4 and microbial dataset, and further applied the model to understand the topographic controls on CH4 flux (Wang et al., 2019); the site-level model has been upscaled to eddy covariance tower domain to understand the CH4 flux from different footprints (Wang et al, 2021). The non-growing seasons have a substantial contribution to the annual budget of CH4 at the Arctic sites (Wang et al, 2019, 2021).
  • Helped to better quantify the contribution of respiration during the fall zero curtain to the annual budget (Watts et al., 2021; Natali et al., 2019). 

Broader Impacts: Our team has been working closely with the Alaska Native Corporation Ukpeaġvik Iñupiat Corporation (UIC) to develop a variety of activities to share the knowledge acquired by this project, and a general knowledge of the effect of climate change on the Arctic with the community and native school children. We disseminated the research results also to the wider scientific community through several EGU sessions we organized in collaboration with scientists from several other institutions in the US and Europe. Our research continued to be featured in the media, for example EOS highlighted the research published by one of the PhD students (Kyle Arndt) (“Methane-Releasing Tundra Soils Freezing Later Each Year”) supported by this grant (and supervised by D. Zona and W. Oechel).
